<div class="section" title="15.6. Master" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h2 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3; clear:both">
<a target="_blank" name="t449" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.master" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.10. Master</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title="15.6.1. 启动错误" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px"></div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Master 更多信息, 参考 <a target="_blank" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#master" rel="nofollow" title="9.5. Master" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Section 9.5, “Master”</a>.</p>
<div title="12.10.1. Startup Errors" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t450" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.master.startup" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.10.1. <span class="title">启动错误</span></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div title="12.10.1.1. Master says that you need to run the hbase migrations script" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t451" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.master.startup.migration" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.10.1.1. Master says that you need to run the hbase migrations script</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Upon running that, the hbase migrations script says no files in root directory.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
HBase expects the root directory to either not exist, or to have already been initialized by hbase running a previous time. If you create a new directory for HBase using Hadoop DFS, this error will occur. Make sure the HBase root directory does not currently
 exist or has been initialized by a previous run of HBase. Sure fire solution is to just use Hadoop dfs to delete the HBase root and let HBase create and initialize the directory itself.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div title="12.10.2. Shutdown Errors" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t452" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.master.shutdown" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.10.2. <span class="title">终止错误</span></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title="15.6.2. 终止错误" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h2 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t453" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.zookeeper" id="trouble.zookeeper" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.11. ZooKeeper</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div title="12.11.1. Startup Errors" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t454" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.zookeeper.startup" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.11.1. 启动错误</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div title="12.11.1.1. Could not find my address: xyz in list of ZooKeeper quorum servers" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t455" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.zookeeper.startup.address" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.11.1.1. 找不到地址: xyz in list of ZooKeeper quorum servers</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
A ZooKeeper server wasn't able to start, throws that error. xyz is the name of your server.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
This is a name lookup problem. HBase tries to start a ZooKeeper server on some machine but that machine isn't able to find itself in the hbase.zookeeper.quorumconfiguration.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Use the hostname presented in the error message instead of the value you used. If you have a DNS server, you can set hbase.zookeeper.dns.interface andhbase.zookeeper.dns.nameserver in hbase-site.xml to make sure it resolves to the correct FQDN.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div title="12.11.2. ZooKeeper, The Cluster Canary" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t456" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.zookeeper.general" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.11.2. ZooKeeper, The Cluster Canary</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
ZooKeeper is the cluster's "canary in the mineshaft". It'll be the first to notice issues if any so making sure its happy is the short-cut to a humming cluster.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
参考  <a target="_blank" href="http://wiki.apache.org/hadoop/ZooKeeper/Troubleshooting" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">ZooKeeper Operating Environment Troubleshooting</a> 页。 It has suggestions and tools for checking disk and
 networking performance; i.e. the operating environment your ZooKeeper and HBase are running in.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Additionally, the utility <a target="_blank" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#trouble.tools.builtin.zkcli" rel="nofollow" title="12.4.1.3. zkcli" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Section 12.4.1.3, “zkcli”</a> may help investigate ZooKeeper
 issues.</p>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
 </p>
<div class="section" title="12.12. Amazon EC2" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h2 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3; clear:both">
<a target="_blank" name="t457" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.ec2" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.12. Amazon EC2</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title="12.12.1. ZooKeeper does not seem to work on Amazon EC2" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t458" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.ec2.zookeeper" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.12.1. ZooKeeper 在 Amazon EC2上看起来不工作？</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
HBase does not start when deployed as Amazon EC2 instances. Exceptions like the below appear in the Master and/or RegionServer logs:</p>
<pre code_snippet_id="615022" snippet_file_name="blog_20150309_112_4968486" class="programlisting" name="code" style="white-space: pre-wrap; word-wrap: break-word; margin-top: 0.75em; margin-bottom: 0.75em; line-height: 1; padding: 1ex; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); background-color: rgb(238, 238, 238);">  2009-10-19 11:52:27,030 INFO org.apache.zookeeper.ClientCnxn: Attempting
  connection to server ec2-174-129-15-236.compute-1.amazonaws.com/10.244.9.171:2181
  2009-10-19 11:52:27,032 WARN org.apache.zookeeper.ClientCnxn: Exception
  closing session 0x0 to sun.nio.ch.SelectionKeyImpl@656dc861
  java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused
             </pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Security group policy is blocking the ZooKeeper port on a public address. Use the internal EC2 host names when configuring the ZooKeeper quorum peer list.</p>
</div>
<div class="section" title="12.12.2. Instability on Amazon EC2" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t459" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.ec2.instability" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.12.2.  Amazon EC2 上不稳定？</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
关于 HBase 和Amazon EC2 的问题，经常在HBase 讨论列表上被问起。搜索旧线索，使用 <a target="_blank" class="link" href="http://search-hadoop.com/" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Search Hadoop</a></p>
</div>
<div class="section" title="12.12.3. Remote Java Connection into EC2 Cluster Not Working" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t460" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.ec2.connection" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.12.3. 远程Java连接到EC2集群不工作</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
参考 Andrew回复，更新在用户列表：<a target="_blank" class="link" href="http://search-hadoop.com/m/sPdqNFAwyg2" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Remote Java client connection into EC2 instance</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title="12.13. HBase and Hadoop version issues" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h2 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3; clear:both">
<a target="_blank" name="t461" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.versions" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.13. HBase 和 Hadoop 版本问题</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title="12.13.1. NoClassDefFoundError when trying to run 0.90.x on hadoop-0.20.205.x (or hadoop-1.0.x)" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t462" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="trouble.versions.205" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>12.13.1. 当想在adoop-0.20.205.x (或 hadoop-1.0.x)运行 0.90.x 时报<code class="code">NoClassDefFoundError</code></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
HBase 0.90.x does not ship with hadoop-0.20.205.x, etc. To make it run, you need to replace the hadoop jars that HBase shipped with in its <code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">lib</code> directory with those of the Hadoop you want to run HBase
 on. If even after replacing Hadoop jars you get the below exception:</p>
<pre code_snippet_id="615022" snippet_file_name="blog_20150309_113_9169358" class="programlisting" name="code" style="white-space: pre-wrap; word-wrap: break-word; margin-top: 0.75em; margin-bottom: 0.75em; line-height: 1; padding: 1ex; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); background-color: rgb(238, 238, 238);">sv4r6s38: Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/commons/configuration/Configuration
sv4r6s38:       at org.apache.hadoop.metrics2.lib.DefaultMetricsSystem.&lt;init&gt;(DefaultMetricsSystem.java:37)
sv4r6s38:       at org.apache.hadoop.metrics2.lib.DefaultMetricsSystem.&lt;clinit&gt;(DefaultMetricsSystem.java:34)
sv4r6s38:       at org.apache.hadoop.security.UgiInstrumentation.create(UgiInstrumentation.java:51)
sv4r6s38:       at org.apache.hadoop.security.UserGroupInformation.initialize(UserGroupInformation.java:209)
sv4r6s38:       at org.apache.hadoop.security.UserGroupInformation.ensureInitialized(UserGroupInformation.java:177)
sv4r6s38:       at org.apache.hadoop.security.UserGroupInformation.isSecurityEnabled(UserGroupInformation.java:229)
sv4r6s38:       at org.apache.hadoop.security.KerberosName.&lt;clinit&gt;(KerberosName.java:83)
sv4r6s38:       at org.apache.hadoop.security.UserGroupInformation.initialize(UserGroupInformation.java:202)
sv4r6s38:       at org.apache.hadoop.security.UserGroupInformation.ensureInitialized(UserGroupInformation.java:177)
</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
you need to copy under <code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">hbase/lib</code>, the <code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">commons-configuration-X.jar</code> you find in your Hadoop's <code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">lib</code> directory.
 That should fix the above complaint.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="section" title="13.1. Overview" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h2 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3; clear:both">
<a target="_blank" name="t465" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="casestudies.overview" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.1. 概述</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
This chapter will describe a variety of performance and troubleshooting case studies that can provide a useful blueprint on diagnosing cluster issues.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
For more information on Performance and Troubleshooting, see <a target="_blank" class="xref" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#performance" rel="nofollow" title="Chapter 11. Performance Tuning" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Chapter 11, <em>Performance
 Tuning</em></a> and <a target="_blank" class="xref" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#trouble" rel="nofollow" title="Chapter 12. Troubleshooting and Debugging HBase" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Chapter 12, <em>Troubleshooting and
 Debugging HBase</em></a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title="13.2. Schema Design" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h2 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3; clear:both">
<a target="_blank" name="t466" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="casestudies.schema" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.2. 模式设计</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title="13.2.1. List Data" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t467" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="casestudies.schema.listdata" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.2.1. 数据列表</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
The following is an exchange from the user dist-list regarding a fairly common question: how to handle per-user list data in HBase.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
*** QUESTION ***</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
We're looking at how to store a large amount of (per-user) list data in HBase, and we were trying to figure out what kind of access pattern made the most sense. One option is store the majority of the data in a key, so we could have something like:</p>
<pre code_snippet_id="615022" snippet_file_name="blog_20150309_114_5562841" class="programlisting" name="code" style="white-space: pre-wrap; word-wrap: break-word; margin-top: 0.75em; margin-bottom: 0.75em; line-height: 1; padding: 1ex; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); background-color: rgb(238, 238, 238);">&lt;FixedWidthUserName&gt;&lt;FixedWidthValueId1&gt;:"" (no value)
&lt;FixedWidthUserName&gt;&lt;FixedWidthValueId2&gt;:"" (no value)
&lt;FixedWidthUserName&gt;&lt;FixedWidthValueId3&gt;:"" (no value)
			</pre>The other option we had was to do this entirely using:<pre code_snippet_id="615022" snippet_file_name="blog_20150309_115_2271969" class="programlisting" name="code" style="white-space: pre-wrap; word-wrap: break-word; margin-top: 0.75em; margin-bottom: 0.75em; line-height: 1; padding: 1ex; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); background-color: rgb(238, 238, 238);">&lt;FixedWidthUserName&gt;&lt;FixedWidthPageNum0&gt;:&lt;FixedWidthLength&gt;&lt;FixedIdNextPageNum&gt;&lt;ValueId1&gt;&lt;ValueId2&gt;&lt;ValueId3&gt;...
&lt;FixedWidthUserName&gt;&lt;FixedWidthPageNum1&gt;:&lt;FixedWidthLength&gt;&lt;FixedIdNextPageNum&gt;&lt;ValueId1&gt;&lt;ValueId2&gt;&lt;ValueId3&gt;...
    		</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
where each row would contain multiple values. So in one case reading the first thirty values would be:</p>
<pre code_snippet_id="615022" snippet_file_name="blog_20150309_116_8698470" class="programlisting" name="code" style="white-space: pre-wrap; word-wrap: break-word; margin-top: 0.75em; margin-bottom: 0.75em; line-height: 1; padding: 1ex; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); background-color: rgb(238, 238, 238);">scan { STARTROW =&gt; 'FixedWidthUsername' LIMIT =&gt; 30}
    		</pre>And in the second case it would be<pre code_snippet_id="615022" snippet_file_name="blog_20150309_117_7948872" class="programlisting" name="code" style="white-space: pre-wrap; word-wrap: break-word; margin-top: 0.75em; margin-bottom: 0.75em; line-height: 1; padding: 1ex; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); background-color: rgb(238, 238, 238);">get 'FixedWidthUserName\x00\x00\x00\x00'
    		</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
The general usage pattern would be to read only the first 30 values of these lists, with infrequent access reading deeper into the lists. Some users would have &lt;= 30 total values in these lists, and some users would have millions (i.e. power-law distribution)</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
The single-value format seems like it would take up more space on HBase, but would offer some improved retrieval / pagination flexibility. Would there be any significant performance advantages to be able to paginate via gets vs paginating with scans?</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
My initial understanding was that doing a scan should be faster if our paging size is unknown (and caching is set appropriately), but that gets should be faster if we'll always need the same page size. I've ended up hearing different people tell me opposite
 things about performance. I assume the page sizes would be relatively consistent, so for most use cases we could guarantee that we only wanted one page of data in the fixed-page-length case. I would also assume that we would have infrequent updates, but may
 have inserts into the middle of these lists (meaning we'd need to update all subsequent rows).</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Thanks for help / suggestions / follow-up questions.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
*** ANSWER ***</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
If I understand you correctly, you're ultimately trying to store triples in the form "user, valueid, value", right? E.g., something like:</p>
<pre code_snippet_id="615022" snippet_file_name="blog_20150309_118_9358865" class="programlisting" name="code" style="white-space: pre-wrap; word-wrap: break-word; margin-top: 0.75em; margin-bottom: 0.75em; line-height: 1; padding: 1ex; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); background-color: rgb(238, 238, 238);">"user123, firstname, Paul",
"user234, lastname, Smith"
			</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
(But the usernames are fixed width, and the valueids are fixed width).</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
And, your access pattern is along the lines of: "for user X, list the next 30 values, starting with valueid Y". Is that right? And these values should be returned sorted by valueid?</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
The tl;dr version is that you should probably go with one row per user+value, and not build a complicated intra-row pagination scheme on your own unless you're really sure it is needed.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Your two options mirror a common question people have when designing HBase schemas: should I go "tall" or "wide"? Your first schema is "tall": each row represents one value for one user, and so there are many rows in the table for each user; the row key is
 user + valueid, and there would be (presumably) a single column qualifier that means "the value". This is great if you want to scan over rows in sorted order by row key (thus my question above, about whether these ids are sorted correctly). You can start a
 scan at any user+valueid, read the next 30, and be done. What you're giving up is the ability to have transactional guarantees around all the rows for one user, but it doesn't sound like you need that. Doing it this way is generally recommended (see here<a target="_blank" class="link" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#schema.smackdown" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">#schema.smackdown</a>).</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Your second option is "wide": you store a bunch of values in one row, using different qualifiers (where the qualifier is the valueid). The simple way to do that would be to just store ALL values for one user in a single row. I'm guessing you jumped to the "paginated"
 version because you're assuming that storing millions of columns in a single row would be bad for performance, which may or may not be true; as long as you're not trying to do too much in a single request, or do things like scanning over and returning all
 of the cells in the row, it shouldn't be fundamentally worse. The client has methods that allow you to get specific slices of columns.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Note that neither case fundamentally uses more disk space than the other; you're just "shifting" part of the identifying information for a value either to the left (into the row key, in option one) or to the right (into the column qualifiers in option 2). Under
 the covers, every key/value still stores the whole row key, and column family name. (If this is a bit confusing, take an hour and watch Lars George's excellent video about understanding HBase schema design: <a target="_blank" class="link" href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_HLoH_PgrLk)" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_HLoH_PgrLk)</a>.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
A manually paginated version has lots more complexities, as you note, like having to keep track of how many things are in each page, re-shuffling if new values are inserted, etc. That seems significantly more complex. It might have some slight speed advantages
 (or disadvantages!) at extremely high throughput, and the only way to really know that would be to try it out. If you don't have time to build it both ways and compare, my advice would be to start with the simplest option (one row per user+value). Start simple
 and iterate! :)</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title="13.3. Performance/Troubleshooting" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h2 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3; clear:both">
<a target="_blank" name="t468" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="casestudies.perftroub" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.3. 性能/故障诊断</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title="13.3.1. Case Study #1 (Performance Issue On A Single Node)" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t469" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="casestudies.slownode" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.3.1. 用例 #1 (单节点性能问题)</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title="13.3.1.1. Scenario" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t470" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="d1934e8563" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.3.1.1.场景</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Following a scheduled reboot, one data node began exhibiting unusual behavior. Routine MapReduce jobs run against HBase tables which regularly completed in five or six minutes began taking 30 or 40 minutes to finish. These jobs were consistently found to be
 waiting on map and reduce tasks assigned to the troubled data node (e.g., the slow map tasks all had the same Input Split). The situation came to a head during a distributed copy, when the copy was severely prolonged by the lagging node.</p>
</div>
<div class="section" title="13.3.1.2. Hardware" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t471" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="d1934e8568" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.3.1.2. 硬件</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Datanodes:</p>
<div class="itemizedlist" style="margin:0px">
<ul class="itemizedlist" type="disc" style="margin:0px 0px 0px 78.015625px; line-height:1.2">
<li class="listitem">Two 12-core processors</li><li class="listitem">Six Enerprise SATA disks</li><li class="listitem">24GB of RAM</li><li class="listitem">Two bonded gigabit NICs</li></ul>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Network:</p>
<div class="itemizedlist" style="margin:0px">
<ul class="itemizedlist" type="disc" style="margin:0px 0px 0px 78.015625px; line-height:1.2">
<li class="listitem">10 Gigabit top-of-rack switches</li><li class="listitem">20 Gigabit bonded interconnects between racks.</li></ul>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
</p>
</div>
<div class="section" title="13.3.1.3. Hypotheses" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t472" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="d1934e8591" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.3.1.3. 假设</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title='13.3.1.3.1. HBase "Hot Spot" Region' style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h5 class="title" style="color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3; margin:0.8em 0px 0px -31.203125px">
<a target="_blank" name="t473" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="d1934e8594" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.3.1.3.1. HBase "热点" 区域</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
We hypothesized that we were experiencing a familiar point of pain: a "hot spot" region in an HBase table, where uneven key-space distribution can funnel a huge number of requests to a single HBase region, bombarding the RegionServer process and cause slow
 response time. Examination of the HBase Master status page showed that the number of HBase requests to the troubled node was almost zero. Further, examination of the HBase logs showed that there were no region splits, compactions, or other region transitions
 in progress. This effectively ruled out a "hot spot" as the root cause of the observed slowness.</p>
</div>
<div class="section" title="13.3.1.3.2. HBase Region With Non-Local Data" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h5 class="title" style="color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3; margin:0.8em 0px 0px -31.203125px">
<a target="_blank" name="t474" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="d1934e8599" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.3.1.3.2. HBase 分区具有非本地数据</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Our next hypothesis was that one of the MapReduce tasks was requesting data from HBase that was not local to the datanode, thus forcing HDFS to request data blocks from other servers over the network. Examination of the datanode logs showed that there were
 very few blocks being requested over the network, indicating that the HBase region was correctly assigned, and that the majority of the necessary data was located on the node. This ruled out the possibility of non-local data causing a slowdown.</p>
</div>
<div class="section" title="13.3.1.3.3. Excessive I/O Wait Due To Swapping Or An Over-Worked Or Failing Hard Disk" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h5 class="title" style="color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3; margin:0.8em 0px 0px -31.203125px">
<a target="_blank" name="t475" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="d1934e8604" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.3.1.3.3. Excessive I/O Wait Due To Swapping Or An Over-Worked Or Failing Hard Disk</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
After concluding that the Hadoop and HBase were not likely to be the culprits, we moved on to troubleshooting the datanode's hardware. Java, by design, will periodically scan its entire memory space to do garbage collection. If system memory is heavily overcommitted,
 the Linux kernel may enter a vicious cycle, using up all of its resources swapping Java heap back and forth from disk to RAM as Java tries to run garbage collection. Further, a failing hard disk will often retry reads and/or writes many times before giving
 up and returning an error. This can manifest as high iowait, as running processes wait for reads and writes to complete. Finally, a disk nearing the upper edge of its performance envelope will begin to cause iowait as it informs the kernel that it cannot accept
 any more data, and the kernel queues incoming data into the dirty write pool in memory. However, using <code class="code">vmstat(1)</code> and <code class="code">free(1)</code>, we could see that no swap was being used, and the amount of disk IO was only a
 few kilobytes per second.</p>
</div>
<div class="section" title="13.3.1.3.4. Slowness Due To High Processor Usage" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h5 class="title" style="color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3; margin:0.8em 0px 0px -31.203125px">
<a target="_blank" name="t476" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="d1934e8615" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.3.1.3.4. Slowness Due To High Processor Usage</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Next, we checked to see whether the system was performing slowly simply due to very high computational load. <code class="code">top(1)</code> showed that the system load was higher than normal, but <code class="code">vmstat(1)</code> and <code class="code">mpstat(1)</code>showed
 that the amount of processor being used for actual computation was low.</p>
</div>
<div class="section" title="13.3.1.3.5. Network Saturation (The Winner)" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h5 class="title" style="color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3; margin:0.8em 0px 0px -31.203125px">
<a target="_blank" name="t477" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="d1934e8629" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.3.1.3.5. Network Saturation (The Winner)</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Since neither the disks nor the processors were being utilized heavily, we moved on to the performance of the network interfaces. The datanode had two gigabit ethernet adapters, bonded to form an active-standby interface. <code class="code">ifconfig(8)</code> showed
 some unusual anomalies, namely interface errors, overruns, framing errors. While not unheard of, these kinds of errors are exceedingly rare on modern hardware which is operating as it should:</p>
<pre code_snippet_id="615022" snippet_file_name="blog_20150309_119_4116145" class="programlisting" name="code" style="white-space: pre-wrap; word-wrap: break-word; margin-top: 0.75em; margin-bottom: 0.75em; line-height: 1; padding: 1ex; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); background-color: rgb(238, 238, 238);">		
$ /sbin/ifconfig bond0
bond0  Link encap:Ethernet  HWaddr 00:00:00:00:00:00  
inet addr:10.x.x.x  Bcast:10.x.x.255  Mask:255.255.255.0
UP BROADCAST RUNNING MASTER MULTICAST  MTU:1500  Metric:1
RX packets:2990700159 errors:12 dropped:0 overruns:1 frame:6          &lt;--- Look Here! Errors!
TX packets:3443518196 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
collisions:0 txqueuelen:0 
RX bytes:2416328868676 (2.4 TB)  TX bytes:3464991094001 (3.4 TB)
</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
These errors immediately lead us to suspect that one or more of the ethernet interfaces might have negotiated the wrong line speed. This was confirmed both by running an ICMP ping from an external host and observing round-trip-time in excess of 700ms, and by
 running <code class="code">ethtool(8)</code> on the members of the bond interface and discovering that the active interface was operating at 100Mbs/, full duplex.</p>
<pre code_snippet_id="615022" snippet_file_name="blog_20150309_120_2494495" class="programlisting" name="code" style="white-space: pre-wrap; word-wrap: break-word; margin-top: 0.75em; margin-bottom: 0.75em; line-height: 1; padding: 1ex; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); background-color: rgb(238, 238, 238);">		
$ sudo ethtool eth0
Settings for eth0:
Supported ports: [ TP ]
Supported link modes:   10baseT/Half 10baseT/Full 
                       100baseT/Half 100baseT/Full 
                       1000baseT/Full 
Supports auto-negotiation: Yes
Advertised link modes:  10baseT/Half 10baseT/Full 
                       100baseT/Half 100baseT/Full 
                       1000baseT/Full 
Advertised pause frame use: No
Advertised auto-negotiation: Yes
Link partner advertised link modes:  Not reported
Link partner advertised pause frame use: No
Link partner advertised auto-negotiation: No
Speed: 100Mb/s                                     &lt;--- Look Here!  Should say 1000Mb/s!
Duplex: Full
Port: Twisted Pair
PHYAD: 1
Transceiver: internal
Auto-negotiation: on
MDI-X: Unknown
Supports Wake-on: umbg
Wake-on: g
Current message level: 0x00000003 (3)
Link detected: yes
</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
In normal operation, the ICMP ping round trip time should be around 20ms, and the interface speed and duplex should read, "1000MB/s", and, "Full", respectively.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title="13.3.1.4. Resolution" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t478" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="d1934e8650" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>13.3.1.4. 结论</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
After determining that the active ethernet adapter was at the incorrect speed, we used the <code class="code">ifenslave(8)</code> command to make the standby interface the active interface, which yielded an immediate improvement in MapReduce performance, and
 a 10 times improvement in network throughput:</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
On the next trip to the datacenter, we determined that the line speed issue was ultimately caused by a bad network cable, which was replaced.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">

<a target="_blank" name="t482" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="ops_mgt" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>Chapter 14. HBase 运维管理</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="toc" style="margin:0px">
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
<strong>Table of Contents</strong></p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
<strong></strong><span class="section"><a target="_blank" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#tools" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">14.1. HBase <span class="title" style="clear:both">工具和实用程序</span></a></span></p>
