will execute "medium" tests only, launching a new JVM for each test-class.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Running</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">mvn test -P runLargeTests</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
will execute "large" tests only, launching a new JVM for each test-class.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
For convenience, you can run</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">mvn test -P runDevTests</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
to execute both small and medium tests, using a single JVM.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.7.3.5. Running tests faster" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t597" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="hbase.unittests.test.faster" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.7.3.5. Running tests faster</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
By default, $ mvn test -P runAllTests runs 5 tests in parallel. It can be increased on a developer's machine. Allowing that you can have 2 tests in parallel per core, and you need about 2Gb of memory per test (at the extreme), if you have an 8 core, 24Gb box,
 you can have 16 tests in parallel. but the memory available limits it to 12 (24/2), To run all tests with 12 tests in parallell, do this: <strong>mvn test -P runAllTests -Dsurefire.secondPartThreadCount=12</strong>. To increase the speed, you can as well use
 a ramdisk. You will need 2Gb of memory to run all tests. You will also need to delete the files between two test run. The typical way to configure a ramdisk on Linux is:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">$ sudo mkdir /ram2G  sudo mount -t tmpfs -o size=2048M tmpfs /ram2G</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
You can then use it to run all HBase tests with the command: <strong>mvn test -P runAllTests -Dsurefire.secondPartThreadCount=12 -Dtest.build.data.basedirectory=/ram2G</strong></p>
</div>
<div title="15.7.3.6. hbasetests.sh" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t598" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="hbase.unittests.cmds.test.hbasetests" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.7.3.6. <strong>hbasetests.sh</strong></h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
It's also possible to use the script <strong>hbasetests.sh</strong>. This script runs the medium and large tests in parallel with two maven instances, and provides a single report. This script does not use the hbase version of surefire so no parallelization
 is being done other than the two maven instances the script sets up. It must be executed from the directory which contains the pom.xml.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
For example running</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">./dev-support/hbasetests.sh</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
will execute small and medium tests. Running</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">./dev-support/hbasetests.sh runAllTests</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
will execute all tests. Running</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">./dev-support/hbasetests.sh replayFailed</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
will rerun the failed tests a second time, in a separate jvm and without parallelisation.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.7.3.7. Test Resource Checker" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t599" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="hbase.unittests.resource.checker" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.7.3.7. Test Resource Checker<a target="_blank" name="d2520e10750" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a></h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
A custom Maven SureFire plugin listener checks a number of resources before and after each HBase unit test runs and logs its findings at the end of the test output files which can be found in target/surefire-reports per Maven module (Tests write test reports
 named for the test class into this directory. Check the *-out.txt files). The resources counted are the number of threads, the number of file descriptors, etc. If the number has increased, it adds a <em>LEAK?</em> comment in the logs. As you can have an HBase
 instance running in the background, some threads can be deleted/created without any specific action in the test. However, if the test does not work as expected, or if the test should not impact these resources, it's worth checking these log lines ...hbase.ResourceChecker(157):
 before... and ...hbase.ResourceChecker(157): after.... For example: 2012-09-26 09:22:15,315 INFO [pool-1-thread-1] hbase.ResourceChecker(157): after: regionserver.TestColumnSeeking#testReseeking Thread=65 (was 65), OpenFileDescriptor=107 (was 107), MaxFileDescriptor=10240
 (was 10240), ConnectionCount=1 (was 1)</p>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.7.4. Writing Tests" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t600" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="hbase.tests.writing" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.7.4. Writing Tests</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.7.4.1. General rules" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t601" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="hbase.tests.rules" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.7.4.1. General rules</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div style="margin:0px">
<ul type="disc" style="margin:0px 0px 0px 78.015625px; line-height:1.2">
<li>As much as possible, tests should be written as category small tests.</li><li>All tests must be written to support parallel execution on the same machine, hence they should not use shared resources as fixed ports or fixed file names.</li><li>Tests should not overlog. More than 100 lines/second makes the logs complex to read and use i/o that are hence not available for the other tests.</li><li>Tests can be written with HBaseTestingUtility. This class offers helper functions to create a temp directory and do the cleanup, or to start a cluster.</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.7.4.2. Categories and execution time" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t602" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="hbase.tests.categories" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.7.4.2. Categories and execution time</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div style="margin:0px">
<ul type="disc" style="margin:0px 0px 0px 78.015625px; line-height:1.2">
<li>All tests must be categorized, if not they could be skipped.</li><li>All tests should be written to be as fast as possible.</li><li>Small category tests should last less than 15 seconds, and must not have any side effect.</li><li>Medium category tests should last less than 50 seconds.</li><li>Large category tests should last less than 3 minutes. This should ensure a good parallelization for people using it, and ease the analysis when the test fails.</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.7.4.3. Sleeps in tests" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t603" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="hbase.tests.sleeps" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.7.4.3. Sleeps in tests</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Whenever possible, tests should not use Thread.sleep, but rather waiting for the real event they need. This is faster and clearer for the reader. Tests should not do aThread.sleep without testing an ending condition. This allows understanding what the test
 is waiting for. Moreover, the test will work whatever the machine performance is. Sleep should be minimal to be as fast as possible. Waiting for a variable should be done in a 40ms sleep loop. Waiting for a socket operation should be done in a 200 ms sleep
 loop.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.7.4.4. Tests using a cluster" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t604" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="hbase.tests.cluster" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.7.4.4. Tests using a cluster</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Tests using a HRegion do not have to start a cluster: A region can use the local file system. Start/stopping a cluster cost around 10 seconds. They should not be started per test method but per test class. Started cluster must be shutdown using HBaseTestingUtility#shutdownMiniCluster,
 which cleans the directories. As most as possible, tests should use the default settings for the cluster. When they don't, they should document it. This will allow to share the cluster later.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.7.5. Integration Tests" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t605" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="integration.tests" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.7.5. Integration Tests</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
HBase integration/system tests are tests that are beyond HBase unit tests. They are generally long-lasting, sizeable (the test can be asked to 1M rows or 1B rows), targetable (they can take configuration that will point them at the ready-made cluster they are
 to run against; integration tests do not include cluster start/stop code), and verifying success, integration tests rely on public APIs only; they do not attempt to examine server internals asserting success/fail. Integration tests are what you would run when
 you need to more elaborate proofing of a release candidate beyond what unit tests can do. They are not generally run on the Apache Continuous Integration build server, however, some sites opt to run integration tests as a part of their continuous testing on
 an actual cluster.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Integration tests currently live under the src/test directory in the hbase-it submodule and will match the regex: **/IntegrationTest*.java. All integration tests are also annotated with @Category(IntegrationTests.class).</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Integration tests can be run in two modes: using a mini cluster, or against an actual distributed cluster. Maven failsafe is used to run the tests using the mini cluster. IntegrationTestsDriver class is used for executing the tests against a distributed cluster.
 Integration tests SHOULD NOT assume that they are running against a mini cluster, and SHOULD NOT use private API's to access cluster state. To interact with the distributed or mini cluster uniformly, IntegrationTestingUtility, and HBaseClusterclasses, and
 public client API's can be used.</p>
<div title="15.7.5.1. Running integration tests against mini cluster" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t606" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="maven.build.commands.integration.tests.mini" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.7.5.1. Running integration tests against mini cluster</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
HBase 0.92 added a verify maven target. Invoking it, for example by doing mvn verify, will run all the phases up to and including the verify phase via the maven <a target="_blank" href="http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-failsafe-plugin/" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">failsafe
 plugin</a>, running all the above mentioned HBase unit tests as well as tests that are in the HBase integration test group. After you have completed</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">mvn install -DskipTests</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
You can run just the integration tests by invoking:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">cd hbase-it  mvn verify</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
If you just want to run the integration tests in top-level, you need to run two commands. First:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">mvn failsafe:integration-test</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
This actually runs ALL the integration tests.</p>
<div title="Note" style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t607" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>Note</h3>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
This command will always output BUILD SUCCESS even if there are test failures.</p>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
At this point, you could grep the output by hand looking for failed tests. However, maven will do this for us; just use:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">mvn failsafe:verify</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
The above command basically looks at all the test results (so don't remove the 'target' directory) for test failures and reports the results.</p>
<div title="15.7.5.1.1. Running a subset of Integration tests" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h5 style="color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3; margin:0.8em 0px 0px -31.203125px">
<a target="_blank" name="t608" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="maven.build.commanas.integration.tests2" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.7.5.1.1. Running a subset of Integration tests</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
This is very similar to how you specify running a subset of unit tests (see above), but use the property it.test instead of test. To just run IntegrationTestClassXYZ.java, use:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">mvn failsafe:integration-test -Dit.test=IntegrationTestClassXYZ</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
The next thing you might want to do is run groups of integration tests, say all integration tests that are named IntegrationTestClassX*.java:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">mvn failsafe:integration-test -Dit.test=*ClassX*</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
This runs everything that is an integration test that matches *ClassX*. This means anything matching: "**/IntegrationTest*ClassX*". You can also run multiple groups of integration tests using comma-delimited lists (similar to unit tests). Using a list of matches
 still supports full regex matching for each of the groups.This would look something like:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">mvn failsafe:integration-test -Dit.test=*ClassX*, *ClassY</pre>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.7.5.2. Running integration tests against distributed cluster" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t609" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="maven.build.commands.integration.tests.distributed" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.7.5.2. Running integration tests against distributed cluster</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
If you have an already-setup HBase cluster, you can launch the integration tests by invoking the class IntegrationTestsDriver. You may have to run test-compile first. The configuration will be picked by the bin/hbase script.</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">mvn test-compile</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Then launch the tests with:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">bin/hbase [--config config_dir] org.apache.hadoop.hbase.IntegrationTestsDriver [-test=class_regex]</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
This execution will launch the tests under hbase-it/src/test, having @Category(IntegrationTests.class) annotation, and a name starting with IntegrationTests. If specified, class_regex will be used to filter test classes. The regex is checked against full class
 name; so, part of class name can be used. IntegrationTestsDriver uses Junit to run the tests. Currently there is no support for running integration tests against a distributed cluster using maven (see <a target="_blank" href="https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-6201" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">HBASE-6201</a>).</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
The tests interact with the distributed cluster by using the methods in the DistributedHBaseCluster (implementing HBaseCluster) class, which in turn uses a pluggableClusterManager. Concrete implementations provide actual functionality for carrying out deployment-specific
 and environment-dependent tasks (SSH, etc). The defaultClusterManager is HBaseClusterManager, which uses SSH to remotely execute start/stop/kill/signal commands, and assumes some posix commands (ps, etc). Also assumes the user running the test has enough "power"
 to start/stop servers on the remote machines. By default, it picks up HBASE_SSH_OPTS, HBASE_HOME, HBASE_CONF_DIR from the env, and usesbin/hbase-daemon.sh to carry out the actions. Currently tarball deployments, deployments which uses hbase-daemons.sh, and <a target="_blank" href="http://incubator.apache.org/ambari/" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Apache
 Ambari</a> deployments are supported. /etc/init.d/ scripts are not supported for now, but it can be easily added. For other deployment options, a ClusterManager can be implemented and plugged in.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.7.5.3. Destructive integration / system tests" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t610" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="maven.build.commands.integration.tests.destructive" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.7.5.3. Destructive integration / system tests</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
In 0.96, a tool named ChaosMonkey has been introduced. It is modeled after the <a target="_blank" href="http://techblog.netflix.com/2012/07/chaos-monkey-released-into-wild.html" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">same-named tool
 by Netflix</a>. Some of the tests use ChaosMonkey to simulate faults in the running cluster in the way of killing random servers, disconnecting servers, etc. ChaosMonkey can also be used as a stand-alone tool to run a (misbehaving) policy while you are running
 other tests.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
ChaosMonkey defines Action's and Policy's. Actions are sequences of events. We have at least the following actions:</p>
<div style="margin:0px">
<ul type="disc" style="margin:0px 0px 0px 78.015625px; line-height:1.2">
<li>Restart active master (sleep 5 sec)</li><li>Restart random regionserver (sleep 5 sec)</li><li>Restart random regionserver (sleep 60 sec)</li><li>Restart META regionserver (sleep 5 sec)</li><li>Restart ROOT regionserver (sleep 5 sec)</li><li>Batch restart of 50% of regionservers (sleep 5 sec)</li><li>Rolling restart of 100% of regionservers (sleep 5 sec)</li></ul>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Policies on the other hand are responsible for executing the actions based on a strategy. The default policy is to execute a random action every minute based on predefined action weights. ChaosMonkey executes predefined named policies until it is stopped. More
 than one policy can be active at any time.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
To run ChaosMonkey as a standalone tool deploy your HBase cluster as usual. ChaosMonkey uses the configuration from the bin/hbase script, thus no extra configuration needs to be done. You can invoke the ChaosMonkey by running:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">bin/hbase org.apache.hadoop.hbase.util.ChaosMonkey</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
This will output smt like:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">12/11/19 23:21:57 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Using ChaosMonkey Policy: class org.apache.hadoop.hbase.util.ChaosMonkey$PeriodicRandomActionPolicy, period:60000  12/11/19 23:21:57 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Sleeping for 26953 to add jitter  12/11/19 23:22:24 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Performing action: Restart active master  12/11/19 23:22:24 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Killing master:master.example.com,60000,1353367210440  12/11/19 23:22:24 INFO hbase.HBaseCluster: Aborting Master: master.example.com,60000,1353367210440  12/11/19 23:22:24 INFO hbase.ClusterManager: Executing remote command: ps aux | grep master | grep -v grep | tr -s ' ' | cut -d ' ' -f2 | xargs kill -s SIGKILL , hostname:master.example.com  12/11/19 23:22:25 INFO hbase.ClusterManager: Executed remote command, exit code:0 , output:  12/11/19 23:22:25 INFO hbase.HBaseCluster: Waiting service:master to stop: master.example.com,60000,1353367210440  12/11/19 23:22:25 INFO hbase.ClusterManager: Executing remote command: ps aux | grep master | grep -v grep | tr -s ' ' | cut -d ' ' -f2 , hostname:master.example.com  12/11/19 23:22:25 INFO hbase.ClusterManager: Executed remote command, exit code:0 , output:  12/11/19 23:22:25 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Killed master server:master.example.com,60000,1353367210440  12/11/19 23:22:25 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Sleeping for:5000  12/11/19 23:22:30 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Starting master:master.example.com  12/11/19 23:22:30 INFO hbase.HBaseCluster: Starting Master on: master.example.com  12/11/19 23:22:30 INFO hbase.ClusterManager: Executing remote command: /homes/enis/code/hbase-0.94/bin/../bin/hbase-daemon.sh --config /homes/enis/code/hbase-0.94/bin/../conf start master , hostname:master.example.com  12/11/19 23:22:31 INFO hbase.ClusterManager: Executed remote command, exit code:0 , output:starting master, logging to /homes/enis/code/hbase-0.94/bin/../logs/hbase-enis-master-master.example.com.out  ....  12/11/19 23:22:33 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Started master: master.example.com,60000,1353367210440  12/11/19 23:22:33 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Sleeping for:51321  12/11/19 23:23:24 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Performing action: Restart random region server  12/11/19 23:23:24 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Killing region server:rs3.example.com,60020,1353367027826  12/11/19 23:23:24 INFO hbase.HBaseCluster: Aborting RS: rs3.example.com,60020,1353367027826  12/11/19 23:23:24 INFO hbase.ClusterManager: Executing remote command: ps aux | grep regionserver | grep -v grep | tr -s ' ' | cut -d ' ' -f2 | xargs kill -s SIGKILL , hostname:rs3.example.com  12/11/19 23:23:25 INFO hbase.ClusterManager: Executed remote command, exit code:0 , output:  12/11/19 23:23:25 INFO hbase.HBaseCluster: Waiting service:regionserver to stop: rs3.example.com,60020,1353367027826  12/11/19 23:23:25 INFO hbase.ClusterManager: Executing remote command: ps aux | grep regionserver | grep -v grep | tr -s ' ' | cut -d ' ' -f2 , hostname:rs3.example.com  12/11/19 23:23:25 INFO hbase.ClusterManager: Executed remote command, exit code:0 , output:  12/11/19 23:23:25 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Killed region server:rs3.example.com,60020,1353367027826. Reported num of rs:6  12/11/19 23:23:25 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Sleeping for:60000  12/11/19 23:24:25 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Starting region server:rs3.example.com  12/11/19 23:24:25 INFO hbase.HBaseCluster: Starting RS on: rs3.example.com  12/11/19 23:24:25 INFO hbase.ClusterManager: Executing remote command: /homes/enis/code/hbase-0.94/bin/../bin/hbase-daemon.sh --config /homes/enis/code/hbase-0.94/bin/../conf start regionserver , hostname:rs3.example.com  12/11/19 23:24:26 INFO hbase.ClusterManager: Executed remote command, exit code:0 , output:starting regionserver, logging to /homes/enis/code/hbase-0.94/bin/../logs/hbase-enis-regionserver-rs3.example.com.out    12/11/19 23:24:27 INFO util.ChaosMonkey: Started region server:rs3.example.com,60020,1353367027826. Reported num of rs:6  </pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
As you can see from the log, ChaosMonkey started the default PeriodicRandomActionPolicy, which is configured with all the available actions, and ran RestartActiveMaster and RestartRandomRs actions. ChaosMonkey tool, if run from command line, will keep on running
 until the process is killed.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.8. Maven Build Commands" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h2 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t611" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="maven.build.commands" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.8. Maven Build Commands</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
All commands executed from the local HBase project directory.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Note: use Maven 3 (Maven 2 may work but we suggest you use Maven 3).</p>
<div title="15.8.1. Compile" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t612" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="maven.build.commands.compile" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.8.1. Compile</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">mvn compile            </pre>
</div>
<div title="15.8.2. Running all or individual Unit Tests" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t613" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="maven.build.commands.unitall" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.8.2. Running all or individual Unit Tests</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
See the <a target="_blank" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#hbase.unittests.cmds" rel="nofollow" title="15.7.3. Running tests" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Section 15.7.3, “Running tests”</a> section above in <a target="_blank" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#hbase.unittests" rel="nofollow" title="15.7.2. Unit Tests" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Section 15.7.2,
 “Unit Tests”</a></p>
</div>
<div title="15.8.3. Building against various hadoop versions." style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t614" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="maven.build.hadoop" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.8.3. Building against various hadoop versions.</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
As of 0.96, Apache HBase supports building against Apache Hadoop versions: 1.0.3, 2.0.0-alpha and 3.0.0-SNAPSHOT. By default, we will build with Hadoop-1.0.3. To change the version to run with Hadoop-2.0.0-alpha, you would run:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">mvn -Dhadoop.profile=2.0 ...</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
That is, designate build with hadoop.profile 2.0. Pass 2.0 for hadoop.profile to build against hadoop 2.0. Tests may not all pass as of this writing so you may need to pass -DskipTests unless you are inclined to fix the failing tests.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Similarly, for 3.0, you would just replace the profile value. Note that Hadoop-3.0.0-SNAPSHOT does not currently have a deployed maven artificat - you will need to build and install your own in your local maven repository if you want to run against this profile.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
In earilier verions of Apache HBase, you can build against older versions of Apache Hadoop, notably, Hadoop 0.22.x and 0.23.x. If you are running, for example HBase-0.94 and wanted to build against Hadoop 0.23.x, you would run with:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">mvn -Dhadoop.profile=22 ...</pre>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.9. Getting Involved" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h2 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t615" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="getting.involved" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.9. Getting Involved</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Apache HBase gets better only when people contribute!</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
As Apache HBase is an Apache Software Foundation project, see <a target="_blank" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#asf" rel="nofollow" title="Appendix H. HBase and the Apache Software Foundation" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Appendix H, <em>HBase
 and the Apache Software Foundation</em></a> for more information about how the ASF functions.</p>
<div title="15.9.1. Mailing Lists" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t616" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="mailing.list" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.9.1. Mailing Lists</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Sign up for the dev-list and the user-list. See the <a target="_blank" href="http://hbase.apache.org/mail-lists.html" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">mailing lists</a> page. Posing questions - and helping to answer other people's
 questions - is encouraged! There are varying levels of experience on both lists so patience and politeness are encouraged (and please stay on topic.)</p>
</div>
<div title="15.9.2. Jira" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t617" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="jira" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.9.2. Jira</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Check for existing issues in <a target="_blank" href="https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Jira</a>. If it's either a new feature request, enhancement, or a bug, file a ticket.</p>
<div title="15.9.2.1. Jira Priorities" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t618" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="jira.priorities" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.9.2.1. Jira Priorities</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
The following is a guideline on setting Jira issue priorities:</p>
<div style="margin:0px">
<ul type="disc" style="margin:0px 0px 0px 78.015625px; line-height:1.2">
<li>Blocker: Should only be used if the issue WILL cause data loss or cluster instability reliably.</li><li>Critical: The issue described can cause data loss or cluster instability in some cases.</li><li>Major: Important but not tragic issues, like updates to the client API that will add a lot of much-needed functionality or significant bugs that need to be fixed but that don't cause data loss.</li><li>Minor: Useful enhancements and annoying but not damaging bugs.</li><li>Trivial: Useful enhancements but generally cosmetic.</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.9.2.2. Code Blocks in Jira Comments" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t619" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="submitting.patches.jira.code" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.9.2.2. Code Blocks in Jira Comments</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
A commonly used macro in Jira is {code}. If you do this in a Jira comment...</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">{code}     code snippet  {code}  </pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
... Jira will format the code snippet like code, instead of a regular comment. It improves readability.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.10. Developing" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h2 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t620" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="developing" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.10. Developing</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.10.1. Codelines" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t621" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="codelines" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.10.1. Codelines</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Most development is done on TRUNK. However, there are branches for minor releases (e.g., 0.90.1, 0.90.2, and 0.90.3 are on the 0.90 branch).</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
If you have any questions on this just send an email to the dev dist-list.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.10.2. Unit Tests" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t622" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="unit.tests" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.10.2. Unit Tests</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
In HBase we use <a target="_blank" href="http://junit.org/" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">JUnit</a> 4. If you need to run miniclusters of HDFS, ZooKeeper, HBase, or MapReduce testing, be sure to checkout the HBaseTestingUtility.
 Alex Baranau of Sematext describes how it can be used in <a target="_blank" href="http://blog.sematext.com/2010/08/30/hbase-case-study-using-hbasetestingutility-for-local-testing-development/" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">HBase
 Case-Study: Using HBaseTestingUtility for Local Testing and Development</a> (2010).</p>
<div title="15.10.2.1. Mockito" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t623" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="mockito" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.10.2.1. Mockito</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Sometimes you don't need a full running server unit testing. For example, some methods can make do with a a org.apache.hadoop.hbase.Server instance or aorg.apache.hadoop.hbase.master.MasterServices Interface reference rather than a full-blown org.apache.hadoop.hbase.master.HMaster.
 In these cases, you maybe able to get away with a mocked Server instance. For example:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">              TODO...                </pre>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.10.3. Code Standards" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t624" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="code.standards" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.10.3. Code Standards</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
See <a target="_blank" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#eclipse.code.formatting" rel="nofollow" title="15.2.1.1. Code Formatting" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Section 15.2.1.1, “Code Formatting”</a> and <a target="_blank" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#common.patch.feedback" rel="nofollow" title="15.11.5. Common Patch Feedback" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Section 15.11.5,
 “Common Patch Feedback”</a>.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Also, please pay attention to the interface stability/audience classifications that you will see all over our code base. They look like this at the head of the class:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">@InterfaceAudience.Public  @InterfaceStability.Stable</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
If the InterfaceAudience is Private, we can change the class (and we do not need to include a InterfaceStability mark). If a class is marked Public but its InterfaceStability is marked Unstable, we can change it. If it's marked Public/Evolving, we're allowed
 to change it but should try not to. If it's Public and Stable we can't change it without a deprecation path or with a really GREAT reason.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
When you add new classes, mark them with the annotations above if publically accessible. If you are not cleared on how to mark your additions, ask up on the dev list.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
This convention comes from our parent project Hadoop.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.10.4. Invariants" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t625" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="design.invariants" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.10.4. Invariants</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
We don't have many but what we have we list below. All are subject to challenge of course but until then, please hold to the rules of the road.</p>
<div title="15.10.4.1. No permanent state in ZooKeeper" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t626" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="design.invariants.zk.data" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.10.4.1. No permanent state in ZooKeeper</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
ZooKeeper state should transient (treat it like memory). If deleted, hbase should be able to recover and essentially be in the same state[<a target="_blank" name="d2520e11190" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#ftn.d2520e11190" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">31</a>].</p>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.10.5. Running In-Situ" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t627" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="run.insitu" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.10.5. Running In-Situ</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
If you are developing Apache HBase, frequently it is useful to test your changes against a more-real cluster than what you find in unit tests. In this case, HBase can be run directly from the source in local-mode. All you need to do is run:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">${HBASE_HOME}/bin/start-hbase.sh</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
This will spin up a full local-cluster, just as if you had packaged up HBase and installed it on your machine.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Keep in mind that you will need to have installed HBase into your local maven repository for the in-situ cluster to work properly. That is, you will need to run:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">mvn clean install -DskipTests</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
to ensure that maven can find the correct classpath and dependencies. Generally, the above command is just a good thing to try running first, if maven is acting oddly.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.11. Submitting Patches" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h2 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t628" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="submitting.patches" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11. Submitting Patches</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
If you are new to submitting patches to open source or new to submitting patches to Apache, I'd suggest you start by reading the <a target="_blank" href="http://commons.apache.org/patches.html" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">On
 Contributing Patches</a> page from <a target="_blank" href="http://commons.apache.org/" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Apache Commons Project</a>. Its a nice overview that applies equally to the Apache HBase Project.</p>
<div title="15.11.1. Create Patch" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t629" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="submitting.patches.create" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.1. Create Patch</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
See the aforementioned Apache Commons link for how to make patches against a checked out subversion repository. Patch files can also be easily generated from Eclipse, for example by selecting "Team -&gt; Create Patch". Patches can also be created by git diff and
 svn diff.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Please submit one patch-file per Jira. For example, if multiple files are changed make sure the selected resource when generating the patch is a directory. Patch files can reflect changes in multiple files.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Make sure you review <a target="_blank" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#eclipse.code.formatting" rel="nofollow" title="15.2.1.1. Code Formatting" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Section 15.2.1.1, “Code Formatting”</a> for code style.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.11.2. Patch File Naming" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t630" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="submitting.patches.naming" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.2. Patch File Naming</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
The patch file should have the Apache HBase Jira ticket in the name. For example, if a patch was submitted for Foo.java, then a patch file called Foo_HBASE_XXXX.patch would be acceptable where XXXX is the Apache HBase Jira number.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
If you generating from a branch, then including the target branch in the filename is advised, e.g., HBASE-XXXX-0.90.patch.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.11.3. Unit Tests" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t631" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="submitting.patches.tests" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.3. Unit Tests</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Yes, please. Please try to include unit tests with every code patch (and especially new classes and large changes). Make sure unit tests pass locally before submitting the patch.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Also, see <a target="_blank" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#mockito" rel="nofollow" title="15.10.2.1. Mockito" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Section 15.10.2.1, “Mockito”</a>.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
If you are creating a new unit test class, notice how other unit test classes have classification/sizing annotations at the top and a static method on the end. Be sure to include these in any new unit test files you generate. See <a target="_blank" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#hbase.tests" rel="nofollow" title="15.7. Tests" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Section 15.7,
 “Tests”</a> for more on how the annotations work.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.11.4. Attach Patch to Jira" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t632" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="submitting.patches.jira" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.4. Attach Patch to Jira</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
The patch should be attached to the associated Jira ticket "More Actions -&gt; Attach Files". Make sure you click the ASF license inclusion, otherwise the patch can't be considered for inclusion.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Once attached to the ticket, click "Submit Patch" and the status of the ticket will change. Committers will review submitted patches for inclusion into the codebase. Please understand that not every patch may get committed, and that feedback will likely be
 provided on the patch. Fear not, though, because the Apache HBase community is helpful!</p>
</div>
<div title="15.11.5. Common Patch Feedback" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t633" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="common.patch.feedback" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.5. Common Patch Feedback</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
The following items are representative of common patch feedback. Your patch process will go faster if these are taken into account <em>before</em> submission.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
See the <a target="_blank" href="http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/codeconv-138413.html" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Java coding standards</a> for more information on coding conventions in Java.</p>
<div title="15.11.5.1. Space Invaders" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t634" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="common.patch.feedback.space.invaders" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.5.1. Space Invaders</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Rather than do this...</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">if ( foo.equals( bar ) ) {     // don't do this  </pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
... do this instead...</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">if (foo.equals(bar)) {  </pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Also, rather than do this...</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">foo = barArray[ i ];     // don't do this  </pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
... do this instead...</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">foo = barArray[i];  </pre>
</div>
<div title="15.11.5.2. Auto Generated Code" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t635" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="common.patch.feedback.autogen" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.5.2. Auto Generated Code</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Auto-generated code in Eclipse often looks like this...</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1"> public void readFields(DataInput arg0) throws IOException {    // don't do this     foo = arg0.readUTF();                                       // don't do this  </pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
... do this instead ...</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1"> public void readFields(DataInput di) throws IOException {     foo = di.readUTF();  </pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
See the difference? 'arg0' is what Eclipse uses for arguments by default.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.11.5.3. Long Lines" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t636" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="common.patch.feedback.longlines" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.5.3. Long Lines</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Keep lines less than 100 characters.</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">Bar bar = foo.veryLongMethodWithManyArguments(argument1, argument2, argument3, argument4, argument5, argument6, argument7, argument8, argument9);  // don't do this  </pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
... do something like this instead ...</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">Bar bar = foo.veryLongMethodWithManyArguments(   argument1, argument2, argument3,argument4, argument5, argument6, argument7, argument8, argument9);  </pre>
</div>
<div title="15.11.5.4. Trailing Spaces" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t637" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="common.patch.feedback.trailingspaces" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.5.4. Trailing Spaces</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
This happens more than people would imagine.</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">Bar bar = foo.getBar();     &lt;--- imagine there's an extra space(s) after the semicolon instead of a line break.  </pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Make sure there's a line-break after the end of your code, and also avoid lines that have nothing but whitespace.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.11.5.5. Implementing Writable" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t638" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="common.patch.feedback.writable" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.5.5. Implementing Writable</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div title="Applies pre-0.96 only" style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t639" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>Applies pre-0.96 only</h3>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
In 0.96, HBase moved to protobufs. The below section on Writables applies to 0.94.x and previous, not to 0.96 and beyond.</p>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Every class returned by RegionServers must implement Writable. If you are creating a new class that needs to implement this interface, don't forget the default constructor.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.11.5.6. Javadoc" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t640" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="common.patch.feedback.javadoc" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.5.6. Javadoc</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
This is also a very common feedback item. Don't forget Javadoc!</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Javadoc warnings are checked during precommit. If the precommit tool gives you a '-1', please fix the javadoc issue. Your patch won't be committed if it adds such warnings.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.11.5.7. Findbugs" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t641" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="common.patch.feedback.findbugs" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.5.7. Findbugs</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Findbugs is used to detect common bugs pattern. As Javadoc, it is checked during the precommit build up on Apache's Jenkins, and as with Javadoc, please fix them. You can run findbugs locally with 'mvn findbugs:findbugs': it will generate the findbugs files
 locally. Sometimes, you may have to write code smarter than Findbugs. You can annotate your code to tell Findbugs you know what you're doing, by annotating your class with:</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">@edu.umd.cs.findbugs.annotations.SuppressWarnings(                      value="HE_EQUALS_USE_HASHCODE",                      justification="I know what I'm doing")</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Note that we're using the apache licensed version of the annotations.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.11.5.8. Javadoc - Useless Defaults" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t642" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="common.patch.feedback.javadoc.defaults" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.5.8. Javadoc - Useless Defaults</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Don't just leave the @param arguments the way your IDE generated them. Don't do this...</p>
<pre style="white-space:pre-wrap; word-wrap:break-word; margin-top:0.75em; margin-bottom:0.75em; line-height:1">  /**     *     * @param bar             &lt;---- don't do this!!!!     * @return                &lt;---- or this!!!!     */    public Foo getFoo(Bar bar);  </pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
... either add something descriptive to the @param and @return lines, or just remove them. But the preference is to add something descriptive and useful.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.11.5.9. One Thing At A Time, Folks" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t643" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="common.patch.feedback.onething" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.5.9. One Thing At A Time, Folks</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
If you submit a patch for one thing, don't do auto-reformatting or unrelated reformatting of code on a completely different area of code.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Likewise, don't add unrelated cleanup or refactorings outside the scope of your Jira.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.11.5.10. Ambigious Unit Tests" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t644" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="common.patch.feedback.tests" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.5.10. Ambigious Unit Tests</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Make sure that you're clear about what you are testing in your unit tests and why.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div title="15.11.6. ReviewBoard" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t645" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="reviewboard" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.6. ReviewBoard</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Larger patches should go through <a target="_blank" href="http://reviews.apache.org/" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">ReviewBoard</a>.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
For more information on how to use ReviewBoard, see <a target="_blank" href="http://www.reviewboard.org/docs/manual/1.5/" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">the ReviewBoard documentation</a>.</p>
</div>
<div title="15.11.7. Committing Patches" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t646" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="committing.patches" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.7. Committing Patches</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Committers do this. See <a target="_blank" href="http://wiki.apache.org/hadoop/Hbase/HowToCommit" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">How To Commit</a> in the Apache HBase wiki.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Commiters will also resolve the Jira, typically after the patch passes a build.</p>
<div title="15.11.7.1. Committers are responsible for making sure commits do not break the build or tests" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h4 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t647" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="committer.tests" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>15.11.7.1. Committers are responsible for making sure commits do not break the build or tests</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
If a committer commits a patch it is their responsibility to make sure it passes the test suite. It is helpful if contributors keep an eye out that their patch does not break the hbase build and/or tests but ultimately, a contributor cannot be expected to be
 up on the particular vagaries and interconnections that occur in a project like hbase. A committer should.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div style="margin:0px"><br>
<hr width="100" align="left" style="margin:0.6em; border-top-width:0px; border-right-width:0px; border-left-width:0px; border-style:solid; border-color:rgb(206,206,206)">
<div style="margin:0px">
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
[<a target="_blank" id="ftn.d2520e10462" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#d2520e10462" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">30</a>] Before 0.95.0, site and reference guide were at src/docbkx and src/site respectively</p>
</div>
<div style="margin:0px">
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
[<a target="_blank" id="ftn.d2520e11190" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#d2520e11190" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">31</a>] There are currently a few exceptions that we need to fix around whether a table is enabled
 or disabled</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title="15.9. Submitting Patches" style="margin:0px">
<div class="section" title="15.9.7. Committing Patches" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h1 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t648" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="zookeeper" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>16. ZooKeeper<a target="_blank" name="d1934e929" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a></h1>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
一个分布式运行的HBase依赖一个zookeeper集群。所有的节点和客户端都必须能够访问zookeeper。默认的情况下HBase会管理一个zookeep集群。这个集群会随着HBase的启动而启动。当然，你也可以自己管理一个zookeeper集群，但需要配置HBase。你需要修改<code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">conf/hbase-env.sh</code>里面的<code class="varname">HBASE_MANAGES_ZK</code> 来切换。这个值默认是true的，作用是让HBase启动的时候同时也启动zookeeper.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
当HBase管理zookeeper的时候，你可以通过修改<code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">zoo.cfg</code>来配置zookeeper，一个更加简单的方法是在 <code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">conf/hbase-site.xml</code>里面修改zookeeper的配置。Zookeep的配置是作为property写在 <code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">hbase-site.xml</code>里面的。option的名字是<code class="varname">hbase.zookeeper.property</code>.
 打个比方， <code class="varname">clientPort</code> 配置在xml里面的名字是 <code class="varname">hbase.zookeeper.property.clientPort</code>. 所有的默认值都是HBase决定的，包括zookeeper, 参见 <a target="_blank" class="xref" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#hbase_default_configurations" rel="nofollow" title="3.1.1. HBase 默认配置" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Section 2.3.1.1,
 “HBase 默认配置”</a>. 可以查找<code class="varname">hbase.zookeeper.property</code> 前缀，找到关于zookeeper的配置。 <sup>[<a target="_blank" name="d613e690" href="http://abloz.com/hbase/book.html#ftn.d352e10649" rel="nofollow" class="footnote" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">33</a>]</sup></p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
对于zookeepr的配置，你至少要在 <code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">hbase-site.xml</code>中列出zookeepr的ensemble servers，具体的字段是 <code class="varname">hbase.zookeeper.quorum</code>. 该这个字段的默认值是 <code class="varname">localhost</code>，这个值对于分布式应用显然是不可以的. (远程连接无法使用).</p>
<div class="note" title="我需要运行几个zookeeper?" style="margin:0px 0.5in">
<h3 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -43.921875px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t649" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="how_many_zks" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>我需要运行几个zookeeper?</h3>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
你运行一个zookeeper也是可以的，但是在生产环境中，你最好部署3，5，7个节点。部署的越多，可靠性就越高，当然只能部署奇数个，偶数个是不可以的。你需要给每个zookeeper 1G左右的内存，如果可能的话，最好有独立的磁盘。 (独立磁盘可以确保zookeeper是高性能的。).如果你的集群负载很重，不要把Zookeeper和RegionServer运行在同一台机器上面。就像DataNodes 和 TaskTrackers一样</p>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
举个例子，HBase管理着的ZooKeeper集群在节点 <span class="emphasis"><em>rs{1,2,3,4,5}.example.com</em></span>, 监听2222 端口(默认是2181)，并确保<code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">conf/hbase-env.sh</code>文件中 <code class="varname">HBASE_MANAGE_ZK</code>的值是 <code class="varname">true</code> ，再编辑 <code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">conf/hbase-site.xml</code> 设置<code class="varname">hbase.zookeeper.property.clientPort</code> 和 <code class="varname">hbase.zookeeper.quorum</code>。你还可以设置 <code class="varname">hbase.zookeeper.property.dataDir</code>属性来把ZooKeeper保存数据的目录地址改掉。默认值是 <code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">/tmp</code> ，这里在重启的时候会被操作系统删掉，可以把它修改到 <code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">/user/local/zookeeper</code>.</p>
<pre code_snippet_id="615022" snippet_file_name="blog_20150309_165_9394655" class="programlisting" name="code" style="white-space: pre-wrap; word-wrap: break-word; margin-top: 0.75em; margin-bottom: 0.75em; line-height: 1; padding: 1ex; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); background-color: rgb(238, 238, 238);">  &lt;configuration&gt;
    ...
    &lt;property&gt;
      &lt;name&gt;hbase.zookeeper.property.clientPort&lt;/name&gt;
      &lt;value&gt;2222&lt;/value&gt;
      &lt;description&gt;Property from ZooKeeper's config zoo.cfg.
      The port at which the clients will connect.
      &lt;/description&gt;
    &lt;/property&gt;
    &lt;property&gt;
      &lt;name&gt;hbase.zookeeper.quorum&lt;/name&gt;
      &lt;value&gt;rs1.example.com,rs2.example.com,rs3.example.com,rs4.example.com,rs5.example.com&lt;/value&gt;
      &lt;description&gt;Comma separated list of servers in the ZooKeeper Quorum.
      For example, "host1.mydomain.com,host2.mydomain.com,host3.mydomain.com".
      By default this is set to localhost for local and pseudo-distributed modes
      of operation. For a fully-distributed setup, this should be set to a full
      list of ZooKeeper quorum servers. If HBASE_MANAGES_ZK is set in hbase-env.sh
      this is the list of servers which we will start/stop ZooKeeper on.
      &lt;/description&gt;
    &lt;/property&gt;
    &lt;property&gt;
      &lt;name&gt;hbase.zookeeper.property.dataDir&lt;/name&gt;
      &lt;value&gt;/usr/local/zookeeper&lt;/value&gt;
      &lt;description&gt;Property from ZooKeeper's config zoo.cfg.
      The directory where the snapshot is stored.
      &lt;/description&gt;
    &lt;/property&gt;
    ...
  &lt;/configuration&gt;</pre>
<h3 style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -46.8125px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t650" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>ZooKeeper 维护</h3>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
Be sure to set up the data dir cleaner described under <a target="_blank" href="http://zookeeper.apache.org/doc/r3.1.2/zookeeperAdmin.html#sc_maintenance" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Zookeeper Maintenance</a> else you
 could have 'interesting' problems a couple of months in; i.e. zookeeper could start dropping sessions if it has to run through a directory of hundreds of thousands of logs which is wont to do around leader reelection time -- a process rare but run on occasion
 whether because a machine is dropped or happens to hiccup.</p>
<div class="section" title="2.2.2.2.2.1. 使用现有的ZooKeeper例子" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h2 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t651" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="d352e10721" id="d352e10721" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>16.1. 和已有的ZooKeeper一起使用</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
让HBase使用一个已有的不被HBase托管的Zookeep集群，需要设置 <code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">conf/hbase-env.sh</code>文件中的<code class="varname">HBASE_MANAGES_ZK</code> 属性为 false</p>
<pre code_snippet_id="615022" snippet_file_name="blog_20150309_166_771629" class="programlisting" name="code" style="white-space: pre-wrap; word-wrap: break-word; margin-top: 0.75em; margin-bottom: 0.75em; line-height: 1; padding: 1ex; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); background-color: rgb(238, 238, 238);">  ...
  # Tell HBase whether it should manage it's own instance of Zookeeper or not.
  export HBASE_MANAGES_ZK=false</pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
接下来，指明Zookeeper的host和端口。可以在 <code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">hbase-site.xml</code>中设置, 也可以在HBase的<code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">CLASSPATH</code>下面加一个<code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">zoo.cfg</code>配置文件。 HBase
 会优先加载 <code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">zoo.cfg</code> 里面的配置，把<code class="filename" style="color:rgb(0,122,0)">hbase-site.xml</code>里面的覆盖掉.</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
当HBase托管ZooKeeper的时候，Zookeeper集群的启动是HBase启动脚本的一部分。但现在，你需要自己去运行。你可以这样做</p>
<pre code_snippet_id="615022" snippet_file_name="blog_20150309_167_4449113" class="programlisting" name="code" style="white-space: pre-wrap; word-wrap: break-word; margin-top: 0.75em; margin-bottom: 0.75em; line-height: 1; padding: 1ex; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); background-color: rgb(238, 238, 238);">${HBASE_HOME}/bin/hbase-daemons.sh {start,stop} zookeeper
            </pre>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
你可以用这条命令启动ZooKeeper而不启动HBase. <code class="varname">HBASE_MANAGES_ZK</code> 的值是 <code class="varname">false</code>， 如果你想在HBase重启的时候不重启ZooKeeper,你可以这样做</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
对于独立Zoopkeeper的问题，你可以在 <a target="_blank" class="link" href="http://hadoop.apache.org/zookeeper/docs/current/zookeeperStarted.html" rel="nofollow" style="color:rgb(255,153,0); text-decoration:none">Zookeeper启动</a>得到帮助.</p>
</div>
<div title="2.5.1. Using existing ZooKeeper ensemble" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section" title="2.5. ZooKeeper" style="margin:0px">
<div class="section" title="2.5.2. SASL Authentication with ZooKeeper" style="margin:0px">
<div class="titlepage" style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<div style="margin:0px">
<h2 class="title" style="margin:0.8em 0px 0px -62.40625px; padding:0px; color:rgb(153,0,0); line-height:1.3">
<a target="_blank" name="t652" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a><a target="_blank" name="zk.sasl.auth" style="color:rgb(255,153,0)"></a>16.2.  通过ZooKeeper 的SASL 认证</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
新版 HBase (&gt;= 0.92)将支持连接到 ZooKeeper Quorum 进行SASL 认证。 ( Zookeeper 3.4.0 以上可用).</p>
<p style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px">
这里描述如何设置 HBase，以同 ZooKeeper Quorum实现互相认证.
